results.content:
I really enjoyed this class.  I think Brian did a very good job.  I'm giving it a slightly less-than-perfect rating though for the following reasons:

* The video still needs some editing (there are spoken edit cues for cutting out material that wasn't cut out)
* There was quite a bit of time spent with encountering/troubleshooting errors.  And while I personally find this to be valuable (as somebody who often encounters self-inflicted problems), I think that the average new developer would be frustrated and confused by this.
* There were a lot of "layers" (GitHub, BitBucket, AppHarbor) that can be a little confusing and most of us would benefit from having it explained a little better.  For example... I'm old-school and I've never used any of them before (I know... it's ridiculous).  So I will need further clarification on why I would need GitHub AND BitBucket.

I'm a relatively older developer with about 18 years in the industry and my skill set has become out-dated and stagnant.  And so I am trying to make time to update that skill set to modern technologies and methods.  This course provided me with a lot of value and I'm certain that I refer back to it for help on some topics.

results.content:
This covers the basics of MVC development and having worked on an MVC project in 2017, I wish I could have spent the time doing this course as it is now clear we did it badly because we didn't understand MVC.

Brian makes the basics very easy to understand and demonstrates all the tools necessary to make MVC easy, or at least to make a solid start. If you are new to web development or need a refresher, there's no better place to start than here.

Thanks Brian.

results.content:
This class was a really positive experience.  I learned new things like Bitbucket & AppHarbor. They're really cool!
@Brian: I just wonder why you didn't use Team Explorer in Visual Studio 2015 to "Commit & Push" changes to BitBucket. It is much more better than Git GUI.

response.content: I wasn't sure Team Explorer was available on the community edition.  It is very easy to work with, you are correct.  I have been using GIT for windows for about 5 years-ish. It was called MSYSGit before.  I *think* at the time there was no GIT option in VS, so I learned it and got used to it.  I have also just recently learned about SourceTree from Atlassian (the same team that make BitBucket and HipChat), so I've been looking into that.  In the end, unless it's guaranteed that Community edition would always allow for GIT integration, a third-party option will always be free and available.  Thanks for the awesome feedback!

results.content:
As an experienced .NET Web Forms developer with no MVC experience, I found this extremely helpful. I liked the instructor's pace and the way he broke up the videos into smaller chunks, which allowed for easier practice and retention. 

I wish he would've gone into some more details of the ViewBag and how it's used, but since this was an introductory course and that can easily grow to an advanced topic, I can see why he left it out.

I was especially pleased with the tutorials on the source control topics, specifically the use of Git For Windows and BitBucket. 

I would gladly take another class from Brian.

I wish he would've gone into some more details of the ViewBag and how it's used, but since this was an introductory course and that can easily grow to an advanced topic, I can see why he left it out.

I was especially pleased with the tutorials on the source control topics, specifically the use of Git For Windows and BitBucket.

I would gladly take another class from Brian.

results.content:
It's a true Lab Reference. It explains what needs to be done to put things to work in a real world scenario of a CRUD web project development and deploy.
Explains how to solve issues that usually popup when we deploy something that works on the dev environment but "for some reason" don't work on the target environment (test or production). 
Also directs us to what can be improved.

Great class, highly recommended.

results.content:
Poor explanation on how data gets passed, from a controller to a view.  The presenter doesn't always sound prepared and comes across as though he is guessing.  And holy heck why did you load up, so many dang media assets in the beginning?  Waste of time spent loading up all of that front end non-sense.  You didn't even explain what a bundle config really is.  If I add a css file to my project why do I need to add it the the bundle file?  Rhetorical question!  Nevermind the poor explanations, of working with migrations and the Unity framework.  Creating new classes with pre-configured content is just lazy.  Working with that incredibly annoying AppHarbor service is infuriating!  Do you think maybe it would have been best to really enforce the concept, of not committing compiled, or custom IDE config files to source control during the source control tutorials and not 5 videos later in a completely unrelated subject!  And why am I dealing with multiple migrations and separate databases again?  Rhetorical question!

IMO...this tutorial may be free, but I would pursue other learning resources.  There are other MVC tutorials through Udemy that, while not "Free", are excellent.  Introduction or not there's just too many key concepts that are skimmed over, or stumbled over in this course.  Super important to understand the purpose, of the MVC architecture model and this presenter fails to deliver on that front.  The domain, URI managment, HTML presentation are all handled very uniquely and require more explanation in an "MVC" tutorial than wasting time grabbing a bunch of ridiculous media assets.

P.S. keep your troubleshooting out of the tutorials.  Make sure your processes work and you have a thorough understanding on how all of the components work before trying to educate others.

There are no Spanish subtitles on any of my courses, and they were never promised.  Sorry for this inconvenience.  This is hardly a reason for a 1-star rating, however, since this is an English course and not a Spanish offering.  

Perhaps get a refund if you are unhappy with the lack of Spanish subtitles, but please reconsider rating the course 1 star because it doesn't have something you could clearly have known it didn't have before buying or taking the course.

results.content:
A good hands-on introduction to ASP.NET MVC for people already familiar at least with some basic full-stack coding, and it includes how to solve common issues by watching the author himself making mistakes, researching the cause and finally explaining the solution.

I feel like too much time is dedicated to the latter part, which can be covered through forums instead, and also some hacks and not-so-clean solutions are best avoided IMHO.

I liked it, recommended to start and the price is unbeatable.
results.content_html:
A good hands-on introduction to ASP.NET MVC for people already familiar at least with some basic full-stack coding, and it includes how to solve common issues by watching the author himself making mistakes, researching the cause and finally explaining the solution.

I feel like too much time is dedicated to the latter part, which can be covered through forums instead, and also some hacks and not-so-clean solutions are best avoided IMHO.

I liked it, recommended to start and the price is unbeatable.

results.content: Brian definitely covered most of the introductory concepts of ASP.NET MVC in a clear and concise manner. However, some aspects of the course, for example the database migrations, could've been improved with more detailed explanations. Overall, this course is a good starting point for anyone interested in learning ASP.NET MVC.

However, some aspects of the course, for example the database migrations, could've been improved with more detailed explanations. Overall, this course is a good starting point for anyone interested in learning ASP.NET MVC.
